College of Materials Science and Engineering Liaoning Technical University Fuxin 123000 China A crucial step in resolving the energy crisis and achieving carbon neutrality is the design of bifunctional allolytic water catalysts with good hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) capabilities because fuel cells are one of the crucial elements of future power systems and require good hydrogen and oxygen ends as fuel internally. In order to investigate the catalytic performance of Mo2C-MoP heterojunction bifunctional catalysts throughout the entire hydrolysis reaction, first-principles construction methods were used. It was discovered that Mo2C-MoP heterojunction catalysts have excellent hydrogen evolution effect under acidic environment through analysis and discussion of electronic properties, adsorption energy, and active sites, especially Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) models effectively adsorb hydrogen atoms near Mo2C with the best Gibbs free energy of 0.02 eV. After that, the Mo2C-MoP(P1) This paper demonstrates that the construction of heterostructured catalysts with different stacking methods has a broad research prospect in the field of fuel cells and provides new ideas for the design of new catalysts and green energy in the future. It provides new ideas for the future design of new catalysts and green energy sources. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords First principles Heterogeneous structure catalysts Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction DFT Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Today, non-renewable energy sources like oil, gas, coal, chemicals, liquefied petroleum gas, and others barely sustain the nation's economic growth and play a fundamental role in the reorganization of our country's energy system [1–3]. Hydrogen energy can be used anywhere in time or space and has the capacity to store energy for immediate use. The use of fossil fuels and environmental pollutants can be significantly reduced by the development of clean energy [4]. In the future, hydrogen and oxygen will play a significant energy role in the development and design of new energy vehicles and new energy mechanical devices. It is also one of the key energy carriers for fuel cells [5,6]. In other words, it is crucial for science that bifunctional electrocatalysts that can catalyze both hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions are developed. Because platinum and palladium, which are currently used as catalysts in fuel cells, are pricey precious metals, creating inexpensive metal electrocatalysts is a crucial step toward the future energy transformation of the world [7]. Due to their comparatively low cost, plentiful supply, superior performance, and great stability in diverse electrolytes, transition metal compounds have drawn a lot of interest in the field of electrolytic hydrogen evolution. The activity and stability of catalysts are improved by the unique electrical structures and chemical characteristics of transition metal phosphides (TMPs) [8,9]. Molybdenum, cobalt, and nickel phosphides are often used phosphides with strong electrochemical activity for hydrogen evolution [10–13]. Researchers have improved the bulk phase materials of molybdenum phosphide (MoP), a highly conductive non-precious metal catalyst, in a variety of ways [14,15]. Common methods of modification include doping MoP with heteroatoms to change its internal electronic structure, altering the phase structure, and building MoP heterostructures to significantly increase its surface area, which will be useful in enhancing the catalytic activity of single-phase TMPs and exposing more active sites. Other common methods of modification include adding carbon substrates to MoP catalysts to increase electrical conductivity [16–19]. The good internal electric field-limited catalysis and intricate effects of the heterostructure design in this case make it of tremendous scientific interest. The heterostructure can increase the accessibility of the active sites, improve the compatibility of the electrolytes, and speed up the interfacial charge transfer, which will change the adsorption/desorption energies of the reactive species and favor changing the behavior of the electrocatalytic process [20]. The prepared catalysts not only displayed low overpotentials (71 mV and 125 V for 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, but also displayed excellent stability in the HER process. These results were obtained by Yiting Xu et al. [19] using a one-step hollow-limited pyrolysis strategy. Excellent electrocatalytic heterostructures have also been created, serving as powerful examples of how heterostructures can improve the electrocatalytic process, including MoP-MoS2 [21], MoP@MoSe2/SnP2O7 [22], MoP/Ni2P [23], and MoP/graphene [24]. Additionally, the near co-lattice of crystals and similar lattice constants make it easier to synthesize biphasic Mo-based transition chemicals [18,19,22]. In addition to the MoP-MoS2 heterostructure electrocatalysts mentioned above, research has also been done on MoP-MoO2 [25], MoP-Mo2N [26], Mo2C-Mo2N [27], MoP-Mo2C [28], and other heterostructures, which offer promising catalytic potential. Using polymer cleavage, Honggang Fu et al. [26] created porous MoP/Mo2N heterojunction nanosheets with good hydrogen evolution activity. In order to demonstrate how chelation and synergistic effects greatly improve the performance of electrolytic water, Jinliang Zhu [28] created a heterogeneous structure of MoP-Mo2C quantum dots that were uniformly distributed on a three-dimensional layered porous carbon fabric. Because the d-band of molybdenum carbide is widened by the overlap of the molybdenum 4d orbital with the carbon 2p orbital in Mo2C, it may be inferred that Mo2C has a d-band electronic structure similar to that of the precious metal platinum (Pt) [29].Although many molybdenum-based structures are being investigated for their HER performance, there is little research on the use of OER, and the research on molybdenum-based compound electrocatalysts is still in the preliminary stages without ideal preparation pathways and theoretical guidance. Based on this, we report a MoP-Mo2C heterojunction electrocatalyst, which achieves bifocal catalytic effect beyond Pt-like precious metals with the help of Mo2C in MoP structure. Through the growth of heterostructures, the heterogeneous electrocatalysts with different stacking methods are described in detail at the atomic level through theoretical calculation. The relationship between orbital state density, reaction free energy and catalytic scale was analyzed to clarify the catalytic effect of HER and OER, and the structural basis of the existing experimental synthesis was pointed out, and then the synthesis method was simplified, hoping to provide design ideas and basis for the design of molybdenum based electrocatalysts. 2 Calculation method In this study, the CASTEP module of the Materials Studio quantum computing program is used to calculate the pertinent electronic characteristics. The truncation energy is assumed to be 450 eV [30] when calculating the exchange correlation energy using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalization function under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). We found that MoP (001) and Mo2C (001) surfaces have strong catalytic activity and can be well manufactured experimentally based on literature investigations, these two crystal faces are used for subsequent stacking and are shortened as MoP [31,32] and Mo2C [33]. The Brillouin zone K-point grid is selected as 7 × 7 × 1 for the structural optimization of the built catalyst model. The grid of K points in the Brillouin zone is chosen as 9 × 9 × 1 for the energy band computation. The K-point of type MonkhorstPack used for the density of states computation is 12 × 12 × 1 [34]. by using the DFT-D approach for weak van der Waals force correction and taking into consideration the strong Coulomb exchange contact between the electrons in the d-energy level of the transition metal [35]. In order to prevent mutual interference of the periodic arrangement and eliminate the interaction forces of the atoms between the layers, the thickness of the vacuum layer is selected to be 20 Å. This allows for the calculation of the electronic structure analysis using the OTFG ultra-soft pseudopotential. After the force and energy criteria exceed 0.1 eV/ and 10−6 eV criterion, respectively, and the maximum displacement tolerance is reached, the geometric structure's optimization is stopped. When the maximum allowed tolerance for displacement is 0.01 Å, the calculation is terminated. At this point, the system's overall energy is also at its lowest, ensuring that the constructed model is more closely related to the crystal's true structure. The dielectric constant is set at 78.54 [36] for the H2O solvent. The NVT system synthesis with a total step size of 5 Ps and a total number of 1500 steps [37] is used to test the computational stability. Other performance calculation methods and guidelines are presented in the accompanying data, and the phonon spectrum of the structure is also calculated to make sure that no spurious frequencies exist in the structure [38]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 A description of the MoP-Mo2C heterostructure's stability Based on their structural characteristics, MoP and Mo2C are divided into four different types of heterostructures, which are referred to as Mo2C-MoP(Mo1), Mo2C-MoP(Mo2), Mo2C-MoP(P1), and Mo2C-MoP(P2), respectively. The layer spacing of heterojunctions is tested, as shown in Fig. S8, and it is found that the layer spacing of the four models is stable at about 2.81 Å, which belongs to the vdws heterojunctions [39,40]. These heterostructures form when molybdenum phosphide P end faces and Mo end faces are exposed on the surface when heterostructures are formed. The adsorption of water on the surface is investigated, and the dissociation process is employed to improve the HER and OER processes with heterostructural synergy, as shown in Fig. 1 (c) [41]. This is accomplished by the C and P 2p orbitals synergistically encouraging d-band modifications. In Table 1 , the lattice parameters of the original Mo2C and MoP structures as well as the heterostructures under various stacks are listed. The overall fitness is within 5 %, indicating that the heterostructures were successfully constructed, that little to no lattice distortion resulted from optimization, and that the catalysts exhibit good structural activity. The system is more stable when molybdenum carbide is coupled with the P-terminus of the layer because all of the catalysts' binding energies are negative. The catalysts' predicted formation energy, cohesion energy, and solubility potential are displayed in Fig. 1(c) and are taken from the supporting data [42–44]. The triangle in the figure indicates that the catalyst can exist steadily and that the metal is not easily dissolved, and the closer it is to the boundary, the more strongly it expresses this according to the various performance rules. As can be shown in Table S1, the built-in catalyst system still has potential stability from a thermodynamic perspective. Once more, it is clear that the Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) models have the best potential for stability. For the aforementioned stable Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) models, the results of kinetic stability tests, molecular dynamics, and phonon spectroscopy are shown in Fig. 2 . The temperature and energy iterations of the system vary and converge clearly in the ab initio molecular dynamics tests (Fig. 2(a) and 2(c)), with the energy iterations convergent at −66,525.257 eV and −66,525.260 eV, respectively. The energy swings are all within 0.002 eV, demonstrating the stability of the system. Furthermore, its dynamics stays stable, and the phonon spectra in Fig. 2(b) and (d) reveal good atomic vibrational frequencies without spurious frequencies. In Table 1, it is examined how the intrinsic transport properties of electrons vary in heterogeneous structures while taking into account their work function and effective mass of carriers. In order to effectively excite surface electrons at lower external energies, where the magnitude of the work function reflects this performance, catalysts have a special aptitude for electron excitation. the Mo2C-MoP(P1) and the Mo2C-MoP(P2) A higher quality of electron leap qualities, which can help with the HER reaction, are reflected in the catalyst's work function, which is lower than that of MoP (3.84 eV). The heterostructures Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) have effective electron and hole masses that are lower than those of MoP, falling from 0.88mh to 0.45me and from 0.62mh to −0.51me , respectively.These findings show that the insertion of Mo2C structures significantly lowers the effective electron and hole masses. Especially with the increased contribution of the effective mass of electrons, this will aid in enhancing carrier mobility. 3.2 MoP-Mo2C heterogeneous structure HER analysis HER activity of several catalyst models was examined once the stability was established, and the hydrogen evolution Gibbs free energy (ΔGH) was frequently utilized as a criterion to investigate the catalyst activity [45]. The "Sabatier" theory states that the adsorbed intermediates' adsorption energy shouldn't be either too strong or too weak because doing so will weaken or strengthen the bonding of the outer electrons, which is bad for the development of good electron interactions and directional transport of the adsorbent on the catalyst surface [46]. The heterostructure's layers contain an area of domain-limited catalysis that is crucial for boosting the catalytic activity [47]. To investigate the practical proton H adsorption sites, five adsorption sites between the layers of the developed heterostructure catalysts were designed. The schematic diagram of the hydrogen evolution sites is shown in Fig. 3 (a). The results of hydrogen evolution free energy are shown in Fig. 3(b) and Table S2, and the two black lines reflect, respectively, ΔGH of 0.2 and −0.2 eV in the area of this location, showing substantial HER activity. First, it is discovered that H adsorption on Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) heterostructures has a Pt-like adsorption capability [48]. It is demonstrated that the P will effectively increase the interlayer electron activity and accelerate the effective migration of electrons into holes in the heterostructure layer. Additionally, the greater HER activity of the adsorbed proton H at the Hd and He positions indicates that the inner surface of Mo2C, particularly at the bridge position (Hd) of Mo atoms, is a favorable location for hydrogen evolution. We are aware that the hydrogen free energy (ΔGH) of Mo2C alone is 1.13 eV, and that after heterojunction has formed, the synergy of MoP activates the active basal plane of Mo2C, which is quite useful for maximizing the reaction activity of Mo-based catalysts. The HER step diagrams of the Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) heterostructures at the Hd and He points are shown in Fig. 4 (a), which follows the investigation of the HER correlation. Fig. 4(b) shows that the catalysts fit the current density-ΔGH volcano curve relationship well, and the catalysts at the top of the volcano curve have outstanding catalytic effect [49]. Due to its excellent electrical conductivity, it has promise for a variety of electrocatalysis applications. The electron orbitals of all Mo2C-MoP catalyst configurations span the Fermi energy level, He is subject to H + adsorption, and all of the catalysts are metalloid following Hd (Figs. S2–S4). The interfacial transport electrons seem to be polarized after the addition of Mo2C, which improves the charge-hole transport separation and significantly boosts the catalytic action. The P-2p and Mo-4d orbital electrons jointly contribute to H-1 s orbitals close to the Fermi energy level, and the HER is made possible by the high electron concentration and ΔGH. Off-domain behavior results from the simultaneous hybridization of the C atom's electronic states with the occupied and unoccupied states of the Mo and P atoms. It is generally known that the d-band center can be utilized to describe the intensity of the interactions between catalysts and adsorbates on various surfaces. While d-band centers that are too distant from the Fermi energy level do not allow for the participation of d-orbital electrons in the reaction, they do promote the adsorption of small molecules on the surface and are more prone to catalyst poisoning [50]. The catalyst's altered d-band center is depicted in Fig. 4(c) following the initial state and hydrogen evolution. The d-band center of Mo changes in the He site of the Mo2C-MoP(P1) structure from −5.22 eV to −4.09 eV. The d-band center of Mo moves from −4.82 eV to −3.99 eV in the He site of the Mo2C-MoP(P2) structure, typically rising. Although the Hd site also has a comparable pattern, the d-band center is considerably closer to the Fermi energy level, which raises questions about the metal's stability and adsorption-dissociation efficiency. This further highlights the superior H + capture and reduction capabilities of the Hd, He sites. The efficient acceleration of the electron transport, the lowering of the catalytic energy barrier, and the increase in catalytic activity caused by the strong contact between MoP and Mo2C were all validated. Additionally, following the development of the heterostructure, there is a notable increase in orbital dispersion towards the Fermi energy level, an indication that the catalytic activity has been improved. With coefficients of determination (R2) of 0.91 and 0.84, it is clear from Fig. 4(d) that there is a considerable linear relationship between the Gibbs free energies of Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) and the molybdenum d-band center. The ΔGH of Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) has a stronger linear connection with the P-band center of P, C, as shown in Fig. 4(e), (f). The scalar relationship between catalyst ΔGH and d-band center and p-band center illustrates, to some extent, the prediction of catalyst ΔGH by transition metal element d-band center and non-metallic element p-band centers, thereby predicting catalyst hydrogen evolution performance and providing recommendations for future catalyst design. When heterostructured catalysts are built, the surface electronic states change, which causes the outer orbitals eg and t2g to reorganize and realign with the orbital center positions and active adsorption energy. This has research implications, and in order to better understand fundamental catalysis, more work and more precise calculation techniques should be put into developing the normative system of heterostructure-electron structure-catalytic activity. The combination of differential charge density and Mulliken charge analysis is the most logical technique to monitor the migration of electrons in electrocatalysts; the specifics are illustrated in Figs. S5–S6, where blue denotes a high electron concentration and red, a low electron concentration. In catalysts with the heterostructure Mo2C-MoP(P1), electrons move from Mo atoms to P atoms. First off, it can make the Mo-P chemical bonding more stable. Secondly, the superior electron transport properties offer a strong foundation for the development of HER. A buildup of electrons near the Mo atom at the Mo2C-MoP interface is visible in the Mo2C-MoP(P2) heterostructured catalyst (Fig.S6), and the resulting electric dipole moment results in improved interfacial bonding. After hydrogenolysis, there was a redistribution of charge, with electrons traveling between the HC and H-Mo chemical bonds in turn, enhancing the HER activity. 3.3 OER analysis of the MoP-Mo2C heterostructure The development of a bifunctional heterogeneous structured allolytic water catalyst is strongly supported by the discovery that the performance pattern of the heterogeneous structured acidic OER primarily occurs in the interlayer don't favor the P-atom side in the adsorption conformation of different intermediates (Fig.S7) and the adsorption site is different from the HER active site without competition [51]. The OH* desorption to O* step, which has the highest free energy change (1.67 eV), is the MoP-controlled reaction rate step, as demonstrated by the specific OER reaction step free energy in Fig. 5 . It is noteworthy that the free energy of the Mo2C /MoP system falls to 2.31 eV vs. 2.34 eV when the reaction reaches this stage (see Fig. 5(c), (d)), it is closer to the theoretical potential of 2.46 eV, indicating that the electronic characteristics of Mo2C, similar to Pt, can adjust the adsorption energy of H2O to facilitate the formation of OOH*, making the steps more balanced and the energy barrier shared by each step more average, so that the high energy barrier value is not only divided into one step, resulting in this step is difficult to occur. Combined with the change of state density in Fig. 6 , it is found that before and after H2O, p-d orbital overlap first increases and then decreases, indicating that the aggregation and dispersion of electron transformation states before and after adsorption affect the change of chemical bond before and after adsorption, and the optimal η value obtained is 0.36 eV, which is also easy to occur for secondary H2O.High ΔG intermediates invariably adsorb to the substrate, reducing the substrate's catalytic activity and making future reactions more challenging. This shows that the Mo2C/MoP heterostructure is dramatically stabilized and the overpotential is significantly reduced by the critical speed step in the desorption of OH* to O* on Mo2C /MoP. Additionally, it confirms the earlier finding from OER experiments that Mo2C plays a role in preventing Mo2+ from oxidizing and stabilizing the O* radical by forming a heterostructure on MoP. The bifunctional catalyst we created has stronger electrocatalytic benefits when compared to the OER activity of previous molybdenum-based borides and carbides [52,53]. The adverse effects of producing hydrogen peroxide were taken into account in addition to OER [54]. However, we discovered that the desire to produce hydrogen peroxide from O* with H2O in an acidic environment requires considerable energy to overcome, which is considerably more than the desire to produce OOH* with H, which shows that the hydrogen peroxide side reaction is difficult to occur. As a result, this chemical route for producing hydrogen peroxide was disregarded. The Mo2C-MoP(P2) bifunctional catalyst with excellent OER activity's orbital modifications during the reaction were examined (Fig. 6). While the Mo and C carrier contributions in Mo2C are primarily present in the conduction band region, the Mo and P carrier contributions in MoP are primarily present in the valence band region. This denotes the separation of electrons and holes on the catalyst's active surface, generating carrier-directed transport, which improves the catalyst's capacity for charge transfer and speeds up the reaction. The bond-breaking dissociation of H2O adsorbed on the surface into OH* and H + as well as deprotonation into O*, on the other hand, are aided by the first and second steps of Mo with large d and the downward shift of the antibond energy level. Combined with Fig. 5, it can also be seen that although the free energy of P2 adsorbed H2O to form OH− is slightly larger, it ensures the balance of the overall reaction, and εd changes significantly in the reaction, reflecting a good charge redistribution between the intermediate state and the catalyst surface, without excessive adsorption and dissociation. After then, the antibond energy band moves northward and the molecular weight of Mo falls noticeably, which makes it easier to trap water on the catalyst surface to produce OOH*. And once more, the drop in d makes O2 easily detach from the catalyst surface. Additionally, the d and p orbits are significantly lower in comparison to Mo2C, demonstrating that the active site of the reaction is mostly on the Mo of MoP, whereas Mo2C primarily functions to stabilize the structure and transport charge. This offers a solid argument in favor of designing bifunctional catalysts. Further discussion is provided on the scalar link between catalyst free energy and characteristic characteristics(Fig. 7 ). We used information from earlier research to create a linear relationship with our created electrocatalysts in order to confirm that Mo-based electrocatalysts had similar OER activity laws [52,53,55]. With a coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.95, GOOH* is represented as ΔG OOH* = 1.52ΔG OH*+2, whereas ΔGO* is represented as ΔG O* = −0.77ΔG OH* + 3.69, with R2 of 0.81. According to the slopes of OOH* and OH* and O* and OH*, which are 1.52 and 0.77, respectively, O* forms double bonds with metal atoms whereas OH* and OOH* create single bonds with them. These high R2 values imply that catalysts with strong OH* binding may also have strong OOH* and O* binding as well as substantial correlation. The scalar relationship between the free energy of adsorption of MoP, Mo2C-MoP(P1), and Mo2C-MoP(P2) intermediates with an applied voltage of 1.23 V and their work function was plotted, with an R2 of 0.91, while the work function can be expressed as W F=−0.15ΔG M*+3.45. As can be seen, the work function and free energy have a strong correlation, and the adsorption intermediate's work function, which is typically around 3.45 eV, is more likely to have a smaller energy change and increase the likelihood of OER steps, which is a good confirmation of Jun Hu's work correlating the work function with HER [56]. The aforementioned linear relationship not only supports the similarity of molybdenum-based catalysts, but it can also be used to efficiently direct catalyst design. 4 Conclusion Few electrocatalysts are able to attain high activity of both HER and OER in the same media due to weak conductivity and severe circumstances in strongly acidic media, which causes excessive overpotential in electrocatalysis to lead to corrosion, agglomeration, or oxidation. Here, using the first-nature principle, we constructed Mo2C/MoP heterojunction catalysts with four stacking orientations and computed their bifunctional catalytic performance for HER and OER. With a maximal overpotential for OER of 0.36 eV and a hydrogen evolution free energy of 0.02 eV, respectively, Mo2C-MoP(P2) is capable of quick HER and OER processes on the Mo2C and MoP surfaces. Additionally, the scalar relationship between the work function and reaction free energy can better direct the creation of superior transition metal electrocatalysts. The creation of heterostructured catalysts using various stacking techniques is shown to have a wide range of research prospects in the field of PEMFC and offers fresh concepts for the design of novel catalysts and green energy in the future. coredata.dc:description: A crucial step in resolving the energy crisis and achieving carbon neutrality is the design of bifunctional allolytic water catalysts with good hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) capabilities because fuel cells are one of the crucial elements of future power systems and require good hydrogen and oxygen ends as fuel internally. In order to investigate the catalytic performance of Mo2C-MoP heterojunction bifunctional catalysts throughout the entire hydrolysis reaction, first-principles construction methods were used. It was discovered that Mo2C-MoP heterojunction catalysts have excellent hydrogen evolution effect under acidic environment through analysis and discussion of electronic properties, adsorption energy, and active sites, especially Mo2C-MoP(P1) and Mo2C-MoP(P2) models effectively adsorb hydrogen atoms near Mo2C with the best Gibbs free energy of 0.02 eV. After that, the Mo2C-MoP(P1) This paper demonstrates that the construction of heterostructured catalysts with different stacking methods has a broad research prospect in the field of fuel cells and provides new ideas for the design of new catalysts and green energy in the future. It provides new ideas for the future design of new catalysts and green energy sources.
coredata.dc:title: Design of Mo2C-MoP heterostructure hydrogen and oxygen evolution bifunctional catalyst based on first principles
